answers.author: Stephen Driscoll
answers.text:
The Brownfields topics is complex, highly technical, and expansive. A discussion on a "starter kit" to begin the conversation between a local government entity and a private enterprise with brownfields issues would be helpful.
Example: How to engage a national railway system to work with a city on rehabilitating a section of land for future economic development.

author: Grant Sparks
text:
The technical program of the ICMA and U.S. EPA cosponsored National Brownfields Conference is the premier forum for learning about and sharing experiences for effectively assessing, cleaning up and redeveloping properties that are abandoned, underutilized or contaminated (also known as brownfields). In today's economy local governments are forced to do more with less, yet many public officials fail to see the economic potential of turning these liabilities into community assets.
Over the years the National Brownfields Conference has grown to a 5,000+ attendee event that focuses more broadly on creating sustainable communities. On May 15-17, 2013 the 2013 National Brownfields Conference will convene in Atlanta, Georgia and I was wondering what session topics you would like to see presented? Here's a short list of what's been covered in years past:

Community Engagement
Economic Development
Green Building
Smart Growth
Community Planning
Environmental Justice
Law and Liability Issues
Insurance Issues
Public Health
Green Technology and Emerging Solutions

If you have a session proposal of your own, please feel free to submit an idea via the conference website -- www.brownfieldsconference.org. Or, if you have any questions, please feel free to contact me, Grant Sparks, at gsparks@icma.org
title: What session topics would attract you to the ICMA cosponsored 2013 National Brownfields Conference?
